uh hi so we've seen how good cluster api is and how the community is going growing
so let's take a closer look at how does it work how does cluster api work well it looks like class api is doing
magic let's go under the hood and actually see how how that magic happens so in cluster api we have this concept
of a management cluster which is responsible for creating and operating a fleet of workload clusters so workload
clusters is where we will deploy our workloads like our kubernetes workloads
and the management cluster can be any kubernetes cluster as long as it is conformant so it could be your local
kind cluster it could be a cluster on any of the managed services like aks eks or it could be another clustered api
created cluster and the important thing to note here is that the same management cluster is creating and operating
clusters across clouds and across various providers at the same time so you can have an aws cluster a gcp
cluster an azure cluster all managed by a single point the management cluster so
the users have to only interact with the management cluster of course through yaml because kubernetes and
and and you can have a fleet of clusters managed by a single point so let's take a closer look at what is
inside the management cluster what makes up the management cluster so you heard the word providers a few times right now
so in cluster api we have four kinds of providers the core provider the
infrastructure provider the control plane provider and the bootstrap provider and these providers extend the
kubernetes api using custom resource definitions commonly referred to as crds
and they come with their own crd definitions and also controllers so the reconcilers as you probably already know
are responsible for maintaining the state between what's actually present and what is the desired state
right so the core providers that we have as part of the core providers we ship some definitions like the cluster
definition the machine deployment definition the machine set and machines the infrastructure provider is the
connector in between that is responsible for interacting with the cloud right so for example if you have an aws provider
it will be it'll know it'll it'll know how to interact with the aws apis for us to be able to do cluster abi things and
then we have a control plane provider which is responsible for initializing our control plane bringing up
bootstrapping and all of those things and then we have a bootstrap provider which is responsible for bootstrapping other worker nodes into
our kubernetes cluster so let's take a closer look at how all of these crds are work in relation with
each other so that we get a better idea of how cluster api operates on some of these new types
so this is a rough tree on the dependencies between the objects that we just saw
the crds that we just saw so at the top left you can see the cluster definition so that's the kind of like the root of
the whole idea and the cluster definition generally holds specifications that are
environment agnostic and it is responsible for maintaining the cluster's life cycle so
environment agnostic configurations like the pod and the service siders and the dns domains those go into the class
definition some of you might have observed the topology section with the comments saying this is an alpha feature we'll go
more into that in a bit uh in a bit it's really interesting so keep that in mind uh next followed by that is the
infrastructure cluster so infrastructure class examples for infrastructure cluster involve the aws cluster the
azure cluster the gcp cluster you can have bare metal bare metal cluster instances and so on so these generally
contain the specification involved for the specific cloud provider so for example the aws cluster will have
configurations on which region you want your cluster to spin up in what ssh key should it use and so on
then comes the control plane the most common control plane at least the one that we ship with capi is the cubedium
based control plane so in the spec you will see that the kuberium configuration is part of the spec like the init
configuration the the init configuration the joint configuration and so on and in the
control plane spec you will also see that there is a reference to the machine deployment machine spec which is used to
define how the underlying machine for those control planes is supposed to look like and it also has
a replicas so that we can scale up and scale on our control planes and also the kubernetes version that we care about
next is the machine deployment so now that we have our control plane defined we need something to define our machine deployments which basically make up our
work nodes so machine deployment to machines is very similar to the
kubernetes deployment to points a deployment in kubernetes represents a collection of parts that are all kind of
similar and emission deployment is exactly the same a machine deployment represents a collection of machines that
are exactly similar that you can scale up scale down and you have a version that you can specify the kubernetes version that you can specify so which
makes up the kubernetes version of the eventual target workload cluster

management as boring as possible and what could be more boring than editing a yaml file right
so this is the cluster definition for the docker cluster that we just created so if we just change the version here
and that is it so we just triggered an upgrade for our cluster you can see that the control plane has picked up the new

first machine the first machine for the control plane at version 123 4 is being created the second and once that is
provisioned the second mission the machine that's already at 123.3 will go down and then the process will start
with the machine deployments right now this upgrade is phased what that means is only after the control plane is
successfully upgraded will it start uh phasing down the upgrades to the machine deployments and if you have
multiple machine deployments it'll do it one at a time

how cluster api handles the rollback i can do a bucket okay yeah so um for a

nodes and that one fails but some of the upgrade went through
so for example like if there's a new lcd version scd gets gets updated um and then you try to roll back they
will be like the the older api server might expect something that scd doesn't you know has changed
um so for these reasons like we prefer usually to to understand why the upgrade was blocked and usually it's like
something like i don't know like for example network containing it was lost or like you just have to retry because
the machine has gone bad or there is misconfiguration um in our experience like we we try to
make upgrades as safe as possible so we don't proceed even like with the first
machine if like all the set of health checks are are okay so like we check at cd it's
like all the member healthy we check the api server controller manager all of those components of the api server
